awd_abstract_narration: Purdue University and CERIAS propose to host three new cohorts of Scholarship for Service (SFS) graduate students. The project builds on the established programs in cybersecurity education and research, and a successful experience as one of the first SFS recipients. The program expects a total of 18 new graduates with an M.S. degree, either in Computer Science or in the Interdisciplinary Masters Degree in Information Security. Some of those graduates may also complete qualifier exams to return to Purdue for a Ph.D. in computer science. The project has an interdisciplinary approach and demonstrates how cybersecurity is more than a technical domain of expertise, but one that must include background in issues related to individual and group behaviors. The SFS students participate in research at the boundaries of these issues as part of their required M.S. thesis or research project.  Students receive special attention in seminar and advising sessions to help them understand the context and role of information security in today's society. This includes regular presentations by leaders in commerce, academia, and government. Through this program students receive a valuable educational background in information security and assurance, obtain hands-on research experience, gain perspective on industry and research trends, and provide valuable service to the government while experiencing real-world problems.

por.por_cntn:
Purdue University was a recipient of a Scholarship for Service award. The original goal was to recruit, educate, and place highly-trained people into positions of national need in cybersecurity. This goal was to be accomplished by offering support to qualified students in the Purdue University Computer Science or Interdisciplinary Information Security (INSC) graduate programs to pursue their degrees in return for qualified employment in the public sector.

The INSC programs was the first cybersecurity degree in the world, and it and the CS degree are both highly ranked by independent observers for their quality and breadth. INSC combined with the CS degree, offers multiple paths to produce highly-trained graduates in the field. Under this grant, 19 individuals received graduate degrees (4 Ph.D. and 15 M.S) and are employed in qualified positions at (among others) the National Security Agency, the National Institutes of Health, the Department of Homeland Security, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, MITRE Corporation, and the Central Intelligence Agency. Other students in these Purdue graduate programs interacted with the SFS students and learned of interesting positions; a few of those non-SFS students also sought public-sector employment at national laboratories and federal agencies. This outcome directly addressed the grant's mission.

In addition to the output of graduates, the grant resulted in an impact from research, including influencing the formation of a state-wide ISAC (Information Sharing and Analysis Center) in Indiana and increased awareness of cybersecurity and digital forensics capabilities for Indiana law enforcement. Other research efforts in protecting public-sector research, digital forensics, cybersecurity training, and anti-phishing technologies were conducted. All of these efforts enhanced on-going research and educational activities, especially those undertaken at Purdue University. Ultimately, these results affect industry and government practice.

A second outcome of the program was a new collaborative course named INSuRE. 23 universities in the USA have adopted this course. In the class, students address real-world problems are presented by partners in federal agencies and major corporations. The students also receive mentoring from senior experts from those organizations. The students in this course solve significant, real-world problems in cybersecurity while enhancing and growing their skills. The course is now in its 7th year and continuing to gain partners nationally. Hundreds of students have participated, and this has led to a better-trained cyber workforce as well as solutions to some vexing security problems.

A third activity conducted under the grant was convening a focused workshop on how to enhance and expand the goals of the SFS program, generally: to recruit, educate, and place highly-trained people into positions of national need in cybersecurity. The workshop brought together individuals from academia, K-12 education, companies, government agencies, non-profits, and other stakeholders to explore issues of how to expand the "pipeline" of potential students of cybersecurity and to enhance their education. The workshop generated many ideas, and a final report on these results is in preparation.

A fourth outcome of the program was a refinement of the Purdue graduate offerings. Through the evolution of the INSC program and participation by SFS students, the program has gained in breadth. It is expanding to offer a pathway for students to complete both a comprehensive B.S. and M.S. degree in five years. This expansion is adding to the existing mechanisms to increase the number of graduates who will work in cybersecurity. We anticipate that other universities will consider adopting this concept, similar to how they have used the ideas in the Purdue INSC program in developing their own cybersecurity degrees.

Thus, in terms of intellectual merit, we have developed new research in several new areas of cybersecurity research and added significantly to the number of well-educated professionals working in the field. It has also resulted in a new research course offered across the nation and enhanced at least one leading research and educational program in cybersecurity. In terms of broader impact, this grant has added capabilities to national institutions, increased awareness of educational needs in cybersecurity, created a model for how to conduct research courses in cooperation with government and industry, and created a model of how to accelerate an educational program producing graduates in an area of critical need.
